seg.output:
Peace and health through Christ.
I have the greatest joy that all of you are in good health, my dearest brother. May I hear this news for a long time, especially that you remain safe for as long as possible in the Lord and in the strength of His spirit. May the Lord Himself increase this health both publicly and privately. We are doing well, especially since our church has been purged of weeds. Our brother Ambrose still remains in Isne. We are not sure of his return, but we hope he has decided to spend the winter with us.
We hear not unfavourable news about the Turkish war, namely that the enemy has vanished. I do not know what fear the Lord has instilled in him, although others attribute this to the power of God or His will. It can be a joyful news if worse things are taken into consideration. But certainly Germany is fighting rather unfavourably, since it is burdened with so much expense almost every other year, even if there is no other danger. The enemy is indeed slippery. For having inflicted damage, killed many, taken many into captivity and destroyed many by fire, he is leaving the land miserably devastated, having certainly achieved what he wanted. He wanted to harm and he has harmed enough and more than enough, returning unexpectedly when he wanted to.

You demand frequent letters from me, which I also expect from you, although I know what kind of business and studies you are occupied with [!]. Even if I had leisure, I still wouldn't have the talent to write. Otherwise I would never write "you are occupied". As much as could be done was done to help this unfortunate one, but not to fulfill a necessity. You do not believe how much cannot be done by us, though we wish it with all our desires.
For the humanity and kindness you showed me when I was with you, I do not cease to give thanks. And through you I greet all the guests and fellows. Add their names.
Above all, I ask that Pellicanus father is safe. May your wife, children, family and all your things be safe too.
I will prepare the inkwell.
Farewell.
Constantia, 26th October 1532.
